elements.content: The mechanical properties of calcium fumarate trihydrate, a 1D coordination polymer considered for use as a calcium source for food and beverage enrichment, have been determined via nanoindentation and high-pressure X-ray diffraction with single crystals. The nanoindentation studies reveal that the elastic modulus (16.7–33.4 GPa, depending on crystallographic orientation), hardness (1.05–1.36 GPa), yield stress (0.70–0.90 GPa), and creep behavior (0.8–5.8 nm/s) can be rationalized in view of the anisotropic crystal structure; factors include the directionality of the inorganic Ca–O–Ca chain and hydrogen bonding, as well as the orientation of the fumarate ligands. High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies show a bulk modulus of ∼20 GPa, which is indicative of elastic recovery intermediate between small molecule drug crystals and inorganic pharmaceutical ingredients. The combined use of nanoindentation and high-pressure X-ray diffraction techniques provides a complementary experimental approach for probing the critical mechanical properties related to tableting of these dietary supplements.

elements.content: In order to study the mechanical properties of a dietary supplement, calcium fumarate trihydrate, a nanoindentation technique was applied. As the indenter tip approaches the sample surface, indentation load (P) and depth (h) are continuously monitored, producing a P−h curve, which leads to the calculations of physical properties such as elastic modulus and hardness. The crystal structure was determined by single-crystal X-ray diffraction, and hence, the mechanical anisotropy is understood with detailed crystallographic analysis.

elements.content: In the past decade, research on inorganic–organic framework materials has been one of the fastest growing areas in materials chemistry because their unique hybrid nature enables the combination of properties from both inorganic and organic materials. Porous metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are of interest for gas storage and separation, drug delivery, as well as for catalysis. It has also become clear that some of the dense phases have eye-catching physical properties for applications in areas that have traditionally been dominated by inorganic materials, for example, ferromagnetism and multiferroics.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In the past decade, research on inorganic-organic framework materials has been one of the fastest growing areas in materials chemistry because their unique hybrid nature enables the combination of properties from both inorganic and organic materials. Porous metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are of interest for gas storage and separation, drug delivery, as well as for catalysis. It has also become clear that some of the dense phases have eye-catching physical properties for applications in areas that have traditionally been dominated by inorganic materials, for example, ferromagnetism and multiferroics.

elements.content: Despite numerous studies on various properties of inorganic–organic framework materials, relatively few studies have contributed to the understanding of an important area, namely, dietary supplements and additives that form hybrid framework structures. These materials are commonly consumed in daily life and play a significant role in the food and pharmaceutical industry. Among the calcium salts which are used as dietary supplements, a number of them are inorganic–organic frameworks with good bioactivity. For instance, calcium gluconate is commonly prescribed as a hypocalcemia treatment, and calcium aspartate is an important supplement. In addition to the calcium compounds, there are many other framework-based dietary supplements and additives, including zinc, magnesium, copper, and potassium derivatives.

In addition to the calcium compounds, there are many other framework-based dietary supplements and additives, including zinc, magnesium, copper, and potassium derivatives.

elements.content: As the most commonly used dosage form for drug delivery, the advantages of using tablets include stability in long-term storage, good portability, low cost, and ease of use by the patients. However, the tableting process of pharmaceutical compacts is rather complex and hence requires a thorough understanding of the pharmaceutical’s crystal structure, as well as its intrinsic elastic and plastic properties. For example, the enhancement of crystal plasticity via slipping in organic pharmaceutical crystals can give rise to better tabletability, since the motions of dislocation along specific slip planes faciliate better compaction. Moreover, properties such as the elastic recovery (the extent of slight rebound in a tablet after the compaction load is removed) during compaction of bulk powders is linked to adverse phenomena, such as laminating and capping.
elements.clean_text: As the most commonly used dosage form for drug delivery, the advantages of using tablets include stability in long-term storage, good portability, low cost, and ease of use by the patients. However, the tableting process of pharmaceutical compacts is rather complex and hence requires a thorough understanding of the pharmaceutical's crystal structure, as well as its intrinsic elastic and plastic properties. For example, the enhancement of crystal plasticity via slipping in organic pharmaceutical crystals can give rise to better tabletability, since the motions of dislocation along specific slip planes faciliate better compaction. Moreover, properties such as the elastic recovery (the extent of slight rebound in a tablet after the compaction load is removed) during compaction of bulk powders is linked to adverse phenomena, such as laminating and capping.

elements.content: The current lack of information on the elastic and plastic responses and the absence of systematic studies of these food materials may be due to the difficulties in preparing high-quality crystals and choosing suitable characterization techniques for understanding the complex structure–mechanical property relationships. The nanoindentation technique, wherein the load and depth of penetration can be measured with a resolution of 1 nN and 0.2 nm, respectively, has facilitated the quantitative characterization of the mechanical properties of single crystals. The measured mechanical properties can, in turn, be utilized for understanding the underlying structural and chemical characteristics of crystals. This has been successfully demonstrated for both inorganic–organic framework materials and organic crystals (including many small molecular pharmaceuticals such as active pharmaceutical ingredients).

elements.content: Calcium fumarate trihydrate, Ca­(C4H2O4)·3H2O (CFT), is classified as a dietary and nutritional additive by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and has recently been considered for use in food and beverage enrichment. The crystal structure of CFT was first reported in 1972. In the present study, we obtained improved crystal structure data under ambient conditions and have examined the mechanical properties of calcium fumarate trihydrate by nanoindentation of single crystals and high-pressure X-ray diffraction. Our comprehensive study reveals the intrinsic elasticity, hardness, stress–strain response, creep, and hydrostatic behavior of this dietary supplememt, which are directly correlated to the underlying crystal structure.
elements.clean_text: Calcium fumarate trihydrate, Ca(C4H2O4)⋅3H2O (CFT), is classified as a dietary and nutritional additive by the U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and has recently been considered for use in food and beverage enrichment. The crystal structure of CFT was first reported in 1972. In the present study, we obtained improved crystal structure data under ambient conditions and have examined the mechanical properties of calcium fumarate trihydrate by nanoindentation of single crystals and high-pressure X-ray diffraction. Our comprehensive study reveals the intrinsic elasticity, hardness, stress-strain response, creep, and hydrostatic behavior of this dietary supplememt, which are directly correlated to the underlying crystal structure.

elements.content: All chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and used as received. Single crystals of CFT were synthesized by thoroughly mixing calcium carbonate (2 mmol, 0.200 g) and fumaric acid (2 mmol, 0.232 g) with 7.5 mL of deionized water. Lathlike translucent crystals were harvested and dried using filter papers after 20 min of growth at room temperature. Phase identification of a ground bulk sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (see the Supporting Information).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Synthesis of CFT 

All chemicals and solvents were of reagent grade and used as received. Single crystals of CFT were synthesized by thoroughly mixing calcium carbonate (2 mmol, 0.200 g) and fumaric acid (2 mmol, 0.232 g) with 7.5 mL of deionized water. Lathlike translucent crystals were harvested and dried using filter papers after 20 min of growth at room temperature. Phase identification of a ground bulk sample was confirmed by X-ray powder diffraction (see the Supporting Information).

elements.content: Ambient pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction was performed on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini Ultra diffractometer with graphite–monochromated Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 300 K (Figure S2). Data reduction was done with CrysAlisPro applying an empirical absorption correction. The structure was solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses, and refined by the full matrix least-squares procedure on F 2 with anisotropic atomic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms using the program SHELX-2013. The program Olex2 was used as an interface for the SHELXS and SHELXL executables. Hydrogen atoms of the fumarate ligand were refined using a riding model and isotropic displacement parameters constrained to 1.2 times those of their adjacent carbon atoms. Positions of the hydrogen atoms of the three water molecules were determined using Fourier difference synthesis and refined using H–O bond length restraints. The crystallographic data are summarized in . CCDC deposition number 926334.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal X-ray Diffraction

Ambient pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction was performed on an Oxford Diffraction Gemini Ultra diffractometer with graphite-monochromated Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) at 300 K (Figure S2). Data reduction was done with CrysAlisPro applying an empirical absorption correction. The structure was solved by direct methods and successive Fourier difference syntheses, and refined by the full matrix least-squares procedure on F 2 with anisotropic atomic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms using the program SHELX-2013. The program Olex2 was used as an interface for the SHELXS and SHELXL executables. Hydrogen atoms of the fumarate ligand were refined using a riding model and isotropic displacement parameters constrained to 1.2 times those of their adjacent carbon atoms. Positions of the hydrogen atoms of the three water molecules were determined using Fourier difference synthesis and refined using H-O bond length restraints. The crystallographic data are summarized in . CCDC deposition number 926334.

High-pressure X-ray diffraction experiments were carried out with a Merrill-Bassett diamond anvil cell (DAC) equipped with 600 μm culet diamonds and a tungsten gasket. The single crystal sample and a ruby sphere (for pressure determination) were loaded into the DAC with paraffin as a hydrostatic medium. The pressure inside the DAC was measured using ruby fluorescence, and the error is ca. 0.1 GPa. Diffraction data were collected on a Rigaku Saturn 724 CCD detector using synchrotron radiation (λ = 0.48590 Å) on beamline I19 at Diamond Light Source (Rutherford Appleton Laboratory, Oxon, U.K.) at four pressure points from ambient pressure, followed by 0.29(8), 1.03(8), and 1.36(10) GPa. Data were collected using ω scans with a step size and exposure time of 0.5° and 1 s, respectively. Unit cell determination and data reduction were performed using CrysAlisPro. An empirical absorption correction was applied. The structure of the first data set recorded at ∼0 GPa was refined starting from the structural model derived from the lab data mentioned above. Subsequent high-pressure structures were refined based on the final model of the preceding data collection. All accessible reflections have been measured, but, because of the constraints of the DAC, data could only be collected to a completeness of about 50% (for θ ≤ 17°). All non-hydrogen atoms were refined with anisotropic displacement parameters; however, some oxygen and carbon atoms were restrained to have quasi-isotropic displacement parameters (ISOR restraint in SHELXL). Hydrogen atoms of the fumarate ligand were refined using a riding model and isotropic displacement parameters (see above). The H atoms on the water molecules could not be located via Fourier difference synthesis and, hence, have not been included in the structural model. The full crystallographic data of the high-pressure diffraction experiments are summarized in Tables S2–S5 (CCDC deposition numbers 1022965–1022968).

elements.content: Individual crystals with well-defined rectangular shapes were selected, and after face indexing using single-crystal X-ray diffraction, the crystals were glued onto small flat aluminum chips using a thin layer of cyanoacrylate glue. Crystals were glued in the way that {100}, {010}, or {001} facets were in contact with the aluminum chips. The samples were then firmly cold-mounted using Epofix resin (Struers Ltd.) and ground to remove the chips, followed by careful polishing using increasingly fine diamond suspensions. A diamond suspension with a particle size of 1 μm was used in the final step to minimize the surface roughness. Nanoindentation experiments were then performed at room temperature using an MTS NanoIndenter XP (MTS Corp., Eden Prairie, MN), with the indenter aligned normal to the {100}, {010}, or {001} facets. A fused silica standard, with an elastic modulus of 72 GPa and hardness of 9 GPa, was used for calibration, and the instrument was kept in an isolation cabinet to minimize thermal instability and acoustic interference. In this study, three sets of measurements have been performed to study the mechanical properties:
elements.clean_text:
Nanoindentation  of Single Crystals

Individual  crystals with well-defined rectangular shapes were selected, and after face indexing using single-crystal X-ray diffraction, the crystals were glued onto small flat aluminum chips using a thin layer of cyanoacrylate glue. Crystals were glued in the way that {100}, {010}, or {001} facets were in contact with the aluminum chips. The samples were then firmly cold-mounted using Epofix resin (Struers Ltd.) and ground to remove the chips, followed by careful polishing using increasingly fine diamond suspensions. A diamond suspension with a particle size of 1 μm was used in the final step to minimize the surface roughness. Nanoindentation experiments were then performed at room temperature using an MTS NanoIndenter XP (MTS Corp., Eden Prairie, MN), with the indenter aligned normal to the {100}, {010}, or {001} facets. A fused silica standard, with an elastic modulus of 72 GPa and hardness of 9 GPa, was used for calibration, and the instrument was kept in an isolation cabinet to minimize thermal instability and acoustic interference. In this study, three sets of measurements have been performed to study the mechanical properties:

elements.content: In the continuous stiffness measurement (CSM) mode, indentations experiments were conducted using a pyramidal sharp Berkovich tip (radius ∼ 100 nm) and were controlled by displacement with a strain rate of 0.05 s–1. The load (P) and the displacement (h) were monitored continuously, until a maximum displacement of 1000 nm was reached, at which point the indenter was held for 30 s before unloading at the same strain rate. Young’s modulus (E s) and indentation hardness (H) of the CFT crystals were obtained from the P–h plots using the standard Oliver–Pharr Method. The diamond indenter used in this study had an elastic modulus of 1141 GPa and a Poisson’s ratio of 0.07. The elastic moduli of the sample determined in the three orthogonal orientations were calculated assuming a Poisson’s ratio of the sample of 0.3.
elements.clean_text:
Young's Modulus and Hardness

In the continuous stiffness measurement (CSM) mode, indentations experiments were conducted using a pyramidal sharp Berkovich tip (radius ~ 100 nm) and were controlled by displacement with a strain rate of 0.05 s-1. The load (P) and the displacement (h) were monitored continuously, until a maximum displacement of 1000 nm was reached, at which point the indenter was held for 30 s before unloading at the same strain rate. Young's modulus (E s) and indentation hardness (H) of the CFT crystals were obtained from the P-h plots using the standard Oliver-Pharr Method. The diamond indenter used in this study had an elastic modulus of 1141 GPa and a Poisson's ratio of 0.07. The elastic moduli of the sample determined in the three orthogonal orientations were calculated assuming a Poisson's ratio of the sample of 0.3.

elements.content: A spherical tip (radius ∼ 10 μm) was used to investigate the elastic–plastic transition of the orthogonal crystal facets during indentation. The indentation stress and strain have been determined according to published procedures.
elements.clean_text:
Elastic-Plastic Transition

A spherical tip (radius ~ 10 μm) was used to investigate the elastic-plastic transition of the orthogonal crystal facets during indentation. The indentation stress and strain have been determined according to published procedures.

elements.content: In the quasi-static mode, where the experiment was load controlled, the effect of anisotropy on creep behavior was studied. With a constant rate of 1.67 mN s–1, samples were loaded using the spherical indenter (R ∼ 10 μm) and held at a constant load of 50 mN for 120 s before being unloaded at the same rate.
elements.clean_text:
Creep Behavior

In the quasi-static mode, where the experiment was load controlled, the effect of anisotropy on creep behavior was studied. With a constant rate of 1.67 mN s-1, samples were loaded using the spherical indenter (R ~ 10 μm) and held at a constant load of 50 mN for 120 s before being unloaded at the same rate.

elements.content: The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study confirmed that CFT crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pna21 with lattice parameters of a = 6.6170(3) Å, b = 17.5812(8) Å, and c = 6.9656(3) Å (), in good agreement with the previous lower resolution study by Gupta et al. The asymmetric unit of CFT contains a Ca­(II) ion, a fumarate ligand with a planar configuration, and three coordinated water molecules (a). The Ca1 atom exhibits a distorted dodecahedral environment and is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two carboxylates of two different fumarate ligands, a chelating carboxylate of the third fumarate, and four coordinated water molecules. Two of these coordinated water molecules bridge to adjacent Ca atoms, while the other two water molecules are terminal. It is noteworthy that only one carboxylate of the fumarate ligand is coordinated to calcium, while the other carboxylate group is involved in hydrogen bonding to the water molecules of neighboring Ca–O–Ca chains. The coordinating carboxylate group of fumarate binds to three Ca­(II) ions in a μ3-η2 bridging mode. As seen in a,d, adjacent Ca­(II) ions are connected via three oxygen atoms, one from water and two carboxylate oxygen atoms, to form a 1D face-sharing CaO8 dodecahedral linkage along the a direction, resembling a chain. These inorganic chains are further interdigitated into a 3D supramolecular network via O–H···O hydrogen bonds between the noncoordinated carboxylate of the fumarate ligand and three coordinated water molecules (b–d), with O···O distances of 2.738(3)–2.936(4) Å (Table S1). We will discuss the details of the intrachain H-bonding in the following paragraphs when rationalizing the elastic properties of CFT.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structure

The single-crystal X-ray diffraction study confirmed that CFT crystallizes in the orthorhombic space group Pna21 with lattice parameters of a = 6.6170(3) Å, b = 17.5812(8) Å, and c = 6.9656(3) Å (), in good agreement with the previous lower resolution study by Gupta et al. The asymmetric unit of CFT contains a Ca(II) ion, a fumarate ligand with a planar configuration, and three coordinated water molecules (a). The Ca1 atom exhibits a distorted dodecahedral environment and is coordinated by two oxygen atoms from two carboxylates of two different fumarate ligands, a chelating carboxylate of the third fumarate, and four coordinated water molecules. Two of these coordinated water molecules bridge to adjacent Ca atoms, while the other two water molecules are terminal. It is noteworthy that only one carboxylate of the fumarate ligand is coordinated to calcium, while the other carboxylate group is involved in hydrogen bonding to the water molecules of neighboring Ca-O-Ca chains. The coordinating carboxylate group of fumarate binds to three Ca(II) ions in a μ3-η2 bridging mode. As seen in a,d, adjacent Ca(II) ions are connected via three oxygen atoms, one from water and two carboxylate oxygen atoms, to form a 1D face-sharing CaO8 dodecahedral linkage along the a direction, resembling a chain. These inorganic chains are further interdigitated into a 3D supramolecular network via O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds between the noncoordinated carboxylate of the fumarate ligand and three coordinated water molecules (b-d), with O⋅⋅⋅O distances of 2.738(3)-2.936(4) Å (Table S1). We will discuss the details of the intrachain H-bonding in the following paragraphs when rationalizing the elastic properties of CFT.

elements.content: (a) An extended asymmetric unit of CFT (symmetry codes: i, −1/2 + x, 3/2 – y, z; ii, 1/2 + x, 3/2 – y, z); atomic displacement ellipsoids are set at 50% probability for Ca, C, and O. (b–d) Crystal structures of CFT viewed along a, b, and c axes. Note that indentations were performed along these three orthogonal axes.

(b-d) Crystal structures of CFT viewed along a, b, and c axes. Note that indentations were performed along these three orthogonal axes.

elements.content: Representative load–indentation depth (P–h) curves obtained from indentation of the three major facets using a sharp Berkovich tip are shown in . The loading parts of all three facets of CFT are smooth, indicating that the plastic deformation, which occurs underneath the Berkovich tip, is relatively homogeneous in nature. As shown in , the average values of E and H () were obtained from repeated indentations in CSM mode and have been calculated over the range from 200 to 1000 nm in order to minimize the effects of indenter tip imperfection and surface roughness. Strongly anisotropic properties () were obtained for specific crystal facets, showing a significant dependence on the underlying crystal structure. The average elastic moduli of the {100}-, {010}-, and {001}-oriented facets are 33.3(6), 16.7(3), and 24.9(6) GPa, respectively, giving E{100}:E{010}:E{001} ratios of 2.0:1.0:1.5. As illustrated in , the inorganic Ca–O–Ca linkages form a stiff backbone structure along the a direction, while these rigid inorganic chains are further linked via weak O–H···O hydrogen bonds along the orthogonal b and c directions. The {100} facet shows the highest elastic modulus since the rigid inorganic linkage can resist a certain amount of elastic deformation.
elements.clean_text:
Elastic and Hardness Anisotropy

Representative load-indentation depth (P-h) curves obtained from indentation of the three major facets using a sharp Berkovich tip are shown in . The loading parts of all three facets of CFT are smooth, indicating that the plastic deformation, which occurs underneath the Berkovich tip, is relatively homogeneous in nature. As shown in , the average values of E and H () were obtained from repeated indentations in CSM mode and have been calculated over the range from 200 to 1000 nm in order to minimize the effects of indenter tip imperfection and surface roughness. Strongly anisotropic properties () were obtained for specific crystal facets, showing a significant dependence on the underlying crystal structure. The average elastic moduli of the {100}-, {010}-, and {001}-oriented facets are 33.3(6), 16.7(3), and 24.9(6) GPa, respectively, giving E{100}:E{010}:E{001} ratios of 2.0:1.0:1.5. As illustrated in , the inorganic Ca-O-Ca linkages form a stiff backbone structure along the a direction, while these rigid inorganic chains are further linked via weak O-H⋅⋅⋅O hydrogen bonds along the orthogonal b and c directions. The {100} facet shows the highest elastic modulus since the rigid inorganic linkage can resist a certain amount of elastic deformation.

Mechanical Properties of <bold>CFT</bold> Determined via Nanoindentation of Single Crystals orientation E (GPa) H (GPa) P y  (GPa) creep rate (nm s–1) {100} 33.3(6) 1.32(6) ∼0.90 ∼0.8 {010} 16.7(3) 1.36(4) ∼0.84 ∼1.9 {001} 24.9(6) 1.05(4) ∼0.68 ∼5.8

Elastic modulus (E) and hardness (H) are calculated from mean values of the CSM data using a Berkovich nanoindenter (Figure ).

Yield stresses (P y ) are extracted from the stress vs strain curves obtained by indentations with a spherical tip (Figure 4 ).

Creep rates are calculated from the h–t plots obtained by indentation with a spherical tip using a quasi-static mode (Figure S5).

Since the strength of a typical hydrogen bonding is considerably lower than covalent bonding and most coordination bonding, the interchain hydrogen bonds along the b and c orientations are more compliant against the indentation stress, which leads to significant mechanical anisotropy along and normal to the orientation of the Ca–O–Ca linkages in CFT. Considering the anisotropy in the structure along the b and c axes, as seen in b,d, adjacent Ca–O–Ca chains are interconnected via hydrogen bonding between the pendent carboxylate groups (O3 and O4) and the three coordinated water molecules (O5w, O6w, and O7w). There are six hydrogen bonds linked to each fumarate ligand, and the orientation of the hydrogen bonding has been analyzed (Table S1), which indicates an ∼30% larger component of the total hydrogen bonding along the c axis than along the b axis. This contributes to the higher modulus normal to the {001} plane than to the {010} plane.
elements.clean_text: Since the strength of a typical hydrogen bonding is considerably lower than covalent bonding and most coordination bonding, the interchain hydrogen bonds along the b and c orientations are more compliant against the indentation stress, which leads to significant mechanical anisotropy along and normal to the orientation of the Ca-O-Ca linkages in CFT. Considering the anisotropy in the structure along the b and c axes, as seen in b,d, adjacent Ca-O-Ca chains are interconnected via hydrogen bonding between the pendent carboxylate groups (O3 and O4) and the three coordinated water molecules (O5w, O6w, and O7w). There are six hydrogen bonds linked to each fumarate ligand, and the orientation of the hydrogen bonding has been analyzed (Table S1), which indicates an ~30% larger component of the total hydrogen bonding along the c axis than along the b axis. This contributes to the higher modulus normal to the {001} plane than to the {010} plane.

elements.content: Hardness represents a material’s ability to resist irreversible deformation under stress, which is a critical factor directly related to determining the tabletability of a pharmaceutical powder. In this study, the hardness values measured for {100}, {010}, and {001} faces are 1.32(6), 1.36(4), and 1.05(4) GPa, respectively, giving H {100}:H {010}:H {001} ratios of 1.3:1.3:1.0 (Figure S3). The {100} and {010} planes exhibit similar degrees of hardness within experimental error. The values of H are affected by both elastic and plastic deformation mechanisms, of which the latter are more active underneath the sharp Berkovich tip. As seen in c, the number of the Ca–O–Ca chains per area along the b axis is higher than that along the c axis, which could result in higher resistance toward permanent deformation, hence larger hardness. On the other hand, plastic deformation in organic and hybrid crystals occurs via slip along specific crystallographic orientations; hence, generally higher mobility of dislocations within the crystal results in more facile plastic deformation. As seen in b, the staggered arrangement of adjacent inorganic linkages and the angle of the fumarate ligands show more flexibility along the c axis, which could facilitate plastic deformation and the development of dislocations along the c axis. As a result, the smallest hardness is observed from the {001} facet.
elements.clean_text: Hardness represents a material's ability to resist irreversible deformation under stress, which is a critical factor directly related to determining the tabletability of a pharmaceutical powder. In this study, the hardness values measured for {100}, {010}, and {001} faces are 1.32(6), 1.36(4), and 1.05(4) GPa, respectively, giving H {100}:H {010}:H {001} ratios of 1.3:1.3:1.0 (Figure S3). The {100} and {010} planes exhibit similar degrees of hardness within experimental error. The values of H are affected by both elastic and plastic deformation mechanisms, of which the latter are more active underneath the sharp Berkovich tip. As seen in c, the number of the Ca-O-Ca chains per area along the b axis is higher than that along the c axis, which could result in higher resistance toward permanent deformation, hence larger hardness. On the other hand, plastic deformation in organic and hybrid crystals occurs via slip along specific crystallographic orientations; hence, generally higher mobility of dislocations within the crystal results in more facile plastic deformation. As seen in b, the staggered arrangement of adjacent inorganic linkages and the angle of the fumarate ligands show more flexibility along the c axis, which could facilitate plastic deformation and the development of dislocations along the c axis. As a result, the smallest hardness is observed from the {001} facet.

elements.content: As shown in , the measured E and H values of CFT are significantly lower than those of other dense hybrid frameworks; however, they are higher than E and H values for the porous zeolitic imidazolate frameworks (ZIFs) and pillared-layered MOFs and are comparable to the metal–formate frameworks, with cavities occupied by ammonium cations. When comparing with other pharmaceutical materials, the E and H of CFT are significantly lower than the values for inorganic food supplements, such as calcium carbonate and magnesium oxide, while being much higher than those of small molecule drug crystals, e.g., caffeine cocrystals, theophylline–methyl gallate cocrystal, and aspirin.

The yield stress, P y , is defined as the transitional stress from elastic to plastic deformation. The {001} plane exhibits the lowest P y , giving P y{100}:P y{010}:P y{001} ratios of approximately 1.3:1.2:1.0 (). As seen in Figure S4, individual values of the yield stress were deduced from the intersection points of the gradient lines in the elastic and plastic regions, respectively. Here, the measured P y has a stochastic nature, although the trend of values for different facets showing the anisotropy within the crystal is consistent. The yield stresses of CFT are lower than the values obtained for the hydrogen bonded 2D hybrid frameworks, such as Cu3(H2O)2­[O3PCH2CO2]2­(polymorph 2), since, the yield stresses are strongly influenced by the directionality of the H-bonding.
elements.clean_text:
Stress-Strain Response and Creep Behavior

The yield stress, P  y , is defined as the transitional stress from elastic to plastic deformation. The {001} plane exhibits the lowest P  y , giving P  y{100}:P  y{010}:P  y{001} ratios of approximately 1.3:1.2:1.0 (). As seen in Figure S4, individual values of the yield stress were deduced from the intersection points of the gradient lines in the elastic and plastic regions, respectively. Here, the measured P  y  has a stochastic nature, although the trend of values for different facets showing the anisotropy within the crystal is consistent. The yield stresses of CFT are lower than the values obtained for the hydrogen bonded 2D hybrid frameworks, such as Cu3(H2O)2[O3PCH2CO2]2(polymorph 2), since, the yield stresses are strongly influenced by the directionality of the H-bonding.

elements.content: By holding the indenter at a constant load in the quasi-static mode, the effect of time-dependent plasticity was examined; the extent of creep is represented by the displacement–time (h–t) curves (). The creep rates are measured from the gradient of the linear segment of the (h–t) curve as ∼5.8, ∼1.9, and ∼0.8 nm/s for {001}, {010}, and {100} facets, respectively. The {001} face exhibits the maximum displacement rate, which has the same order of magnitude as the creep along the hydrogen bonding direction in Cu3(H2O)2[O3PCH2CO2]2, ∼8.6 nm/s). It is apparent that the creep behavior of CFT is strongly affected by the directionality of the hydrogen bonds within the underlying structure since they are inclined to exhibit more plasticity than coordination or covalent bonds. The largest creep along the c axis can be attributed to the easier sliding of the chains along this direction, whereas the rigid Ca–O–Ca inorganic linkage along the a axis gives rise to the least creep. As seen in Figure S5, in order to deform plastically, elastic behavior occurs first and then the Ca–O–Ca chains slip over one another. The pendent fumarate ligands within the Ca–O–Ca chains are more inclined to bend along the c axis compared with that along the b direction, and this contributes to the large creep along the c axis. In addition, the slip in the b direction might be harder due to steric repulsion between Ca–O chains, which is not present for slipping in the c direction.

It is apparent that the creep behavior of CFT is strongly affected by the directionality of the hydrogen bonds within the underlying structure since they are inclined to exhibit more plasticity than coordination or covalent bonds. The largest creep along the c axis can be attributed to the easier sliding of the chains along this direction, whereas the rigid Ca-O-Ca inorganic linkage along the a axis gives rise to the least creep. elements.content: High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at four data points from ambient pressure to 1.36(4) GPa at room temperature (Tables S1 and S2). The evolution of the changes in unit cell volume of CFT as a function of pressure is shown in . The volume decreases almost linearly with increasing pressure, as expected, and the measured percentage of shrinkage is ∼4.3% per GPa in the studied pressure range. The bulk modulus, K 0, of CFT was estimated by using a second-order Birch–Murnaghan equation of state (EoS), giving a value for K 0 of 20.3(4) GPa (). This value is higher than those found in porous coordination polymers or MOFs, but lower than the values for other dense hybrid frameworks, as shown in . Furthermore, the bulk modulus of CFT is significantly higher than those found in small molecule pharmaceutical crystals with weak interactions, e.g., chlorothiazide, piracetam, form V, and d l-mandelic acid, form II; and it is much lower than those of inorganic food supplements, e.g., calcium carbonate and magnesium oxide.

Hydrostatic Behavior

High-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected at four data points from ambient pressure to 1.36(4) GPa at room temperature (Tables S1 and S2). The evolution of the changes in unit cell volume of CFT as a function of pressure is shown in . The volume decreases almost linearly with increasing pressure, as expected, and the measured percentage of shrinkage is ~4.3% per GPa in the studied pressure range. The bulk modulus, K 0, of CFT was estimated by using a second-order Birch-Murnaghan equation of state (EoS), giving a value for K 0 of 20.3(4) GPa (). This value is higher than those found in porous coordination polymers or MOFs, but lower than the values for other dense hybrid frameworks, as shown in . Furthermore, the bulk modulus of CFT is significantly higher than those found in small molecule pharmaceutical crystals with weak interactions, e.g., chlorothiazide, piracetam, form V, and d l-mandelic acid, form II; and it is much lower than those of inorganic food supplements, e.g., calcium carbonate and magnesium oxide.

During the standard in-die compaction process in industry, the displacement of the die punch is fixed. For the powder of randomly oriented crystallites, the elastic recovery of the compacted powder is best related to its bulk modulus (note: different displacements often result in different powder bulk moduli as the powder is not 100% densely packed). The intrinsic bulk modulus of a crystal studied herein is the upper limit of the bulk modulus for its compacted powder form. Hence, the different intrinsic K 0 between pharmaceutical crystals can be used to approximately reflect their discrete elastic recovery during powder tableting. In this sense, the medium K 0 of CFT could indicate an intermediate elastic recovery compared to its organic and inorganic counterparts.

The intrinsic bulk modulus of a crystal studied herein is the upper limit of the bulk modulus for its compacted powder form. Hence, the different intrinsic K 0 between pharmaceutical crystals can be used to approximately reflect their discrete elastic recovery during powder tableting. In this sense, the medium K 0 of CFT could indicate an intermediate elastic recovery compared to its organic and inorganic counterparts.

elements.content: Detailed structural analysis revealed that CFT was compressed with no significant structural changes in the studied pressure range (see Tables S2–S5). As the pressure increases, the Ca–O bond lengths and Ca–O–Ca bond angles within the CaO8 polyhedra do not vary significantly. However, the O···O distances of the hydrogen bonds are compressed slightly from the range of 2.71(3)–2.92(1) Å at ambient pressure to 2.68(4)–2.84(3) Å at 1.36(8) GPa. We observed an initial extension of the b axis with increasing pressure as a result of the strong reduction of the c axis, which forces bonds in the b direction to expand in order to keep the hydrogen bonds at appropriate distances. Beyond 1.03 GPa, the negative linear compressibility of the b axis is no longer seen, since the repulsion between the Ca–O chains has become significant. Hence, in order to further decrease the volume, the fumarate ligands become more interdigitated (i.e., the structure is compressed along the b axis). The shortening of hydrogen bonds under hydrostatic compression observed in CFT is similar to that found in organic pharmaceuticals.
elements.clean_text: Detailed structural analysis revealed that CFT was compressed with no significant structural changes in the studied pressure range (see Tables S2-S5). As the pressure increases, the Ca-O bond lengths and Ca-O-Ca bond angles within the CaO8 polyhedra do not vary significantly. However, the O⋅⋅⋅O distances of the hydrogen bonds are compressed slightly from the range of 2.71(3)-2.92(1) Å at ambient pressure to 2.68(4)-2.84(3) Å at 1.36(8) GPa. We observed an initial extension of the b axis with increasing pressure as a result of the strong reduction of the c axis, which forces bonds in the b direction to expand in order to keep the hydrogen bonds at appropriate distances. Beyond 1.03 GPa, the negative linear compressibility of the b axis is no longer seen, since the repulsion between the Ca-O chains has become significant. Hence, in order to further decrease the volume, the fumarate ligands become more interdigitated (i.e., the structure is compressed along the b axis). The shortening of hydrogen bonds under hydrostatic compression observed in CFT is similar to that found in organic pharmaceuticals.

elements.content: The mechanical properties of a 1D coordination polymer with interchain hydrogen bonding, Ca­(C4H2O4)·3H2O (CFT), were determined by single-crystal nanoindentation and high-pressure X-ray diffraction. The nanoindentation studies reveal that the elastic modulus, hardness, stress–strain relationship, and creep are influenced by the directionality of the inorganic Ca–O–Ca chain and hydrogen bonding as well as the orientation of the fumarate ligands. In addition, high-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies show that the bulk modulus of CFT is about 20 GPa, which is significantly higher than those found in small molecule pharmaceutical crystals constructed via weak interactions, but much lower than the inorganic dietary supplements. Overall, this comprehensive study sheds light on the molecular mechanics of commonly consumed food supplements, which shows that the combination of crystallography and nanoindentation is an effective way to explore the structure–property relationships of hybrid framework materials.
elements.clean_text:
Concluding Remarks

The mechanical properties of a 1D coordination polymer with interchain hydrogen bonding, Ca(C4H2O4)⋅3H2O (CFT), were determined by single-crystal nanoindentation and high-pressure X-ray diffraction. The nanoindentation studies reveal that the elastic modulus, hardness, stress-strain relationship, and creep are influenced by the directionality of the inorganic Ca-O-Ca chain and hydrogen bonding as well as the orientation of the fumarate ligands. In addition, high-pressure single-crystal X-ray diffraction studies show that the bulk modulus of CFT is about 20 GPa, which is significantly higher than those found in small molecule pharmaceutical crystals constructed via weak interactions, but much lower than the inorganic dietary supplements. Overall, this comprehensive study sheds light on the molecular mechanics of commonly consumed food supplements, which shows that the combination of crystallography and nanoindentation is an effective way to explore the structure-property relationships of hybrid framework materials.
